narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We read a large amount of the state formation literature. The syllabus suffers somewhat from being extremely Eurocentric (each non-European region receives one week near the end of the course), although in defense of Didac, this is probably a fair reflection of the literature at large.

Learned about the core ideas prevalent in the state formation literature. This involved why the state formed, how it grew, what the role of the state was, and discussion on state formation in various parts of the world.

This course provides a very strong foundation for the field of state formation, teaches one how to read and challenge research papers (political science), and how to think critically about broad questions such as how to form a state.  I think what this class best imparts is a degree of skepticism towards scientific work and an eye towards how to think about broad, complex issues.
Historical understanding of origins of the state, theories on the rise of European states, assessment of broader applicability

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Didac is very knowledgeable, and does his best to bring the voices of every student into weekly discussions. I also didn't think the amount of readings was as overwhelming as reviews on past iterations of the course seem to indicate.

Weaknesses: There's probably a better way to handle the Eurocentrism of the state formation literature than making each of Latin America, Africa, and Asia one-week topics after nine weeks of Europe-only theory building.

Strengths: Engaging course with interesting readings and a fantastic professor.  The course gave me great insight the foundations of state formation and how to critically analyze research papers (understanding the faults and limitations of research as well as how to better understand state formaiton moving forward).

Strengths: Awesome material and professor

Weaknesses: Online format definitely hurt the course; almost spent too much time critiquing the readings and not enough discussing their implications

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
It's hard to say. The experience I had (as did many other peers I spoke to) largely involved some disappointment with the state formation literature - you read some really bad papers as part of the course, and after a certain point seeing another questionable empirical/identification strategy just gets depressing.

With that said, I did enjoy the course overall, and wouldn't recommend against taking it if you have a genuine interest in the subject.
Yes, if they are interested in the topics at all. The readings are very comprehensive, and Professor Queralt is great at pointing out holes in the arguments that we read.

I would it was a very interesting, albeit challenging course.  The workload is high, but the returns are great as well.  Discussions were stimulating and each class felt like an amazing chance to learn about a very important field.

Yes. The material and the workload can be intimidating (especially with so many grad students) but Prof. Queralt is a fair grader and is great at boiling down the vast amounts of information reviewed in the readings
